channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Winter 2011: Die Ausgabe 20 des Perl-Magazins '$foo' ist da!
item.description: Renee Baecker announcing that the 20th edition of the German $foo Magazin is out. Of course, it is in German.

item.title: Ricardo Signes becomse the new Perl 5 Pumpkin
item.description: Let's thank Jesse Vincent for his excellent work on directing the Perl 5 porters improving Perl in a direction we did not beleive could happen. Then let's thank Ricardo Signes for taking this hard job.

item.title: On Technical Friction and on Technical Debt
item.description: In response to an article by Ovid linked from this article, chromatic explains why he prefers to use the name 'technical friction' where others, use 'technical debt'. Its an interesting discussion.

item.title: Happy Birthday, MetaCPAN!
item.description: Olaf Alders celebrates the first anniversary of MetaCPAN and uses the opportunity to mention the recent changes. If you still have not switched to MetaCPAN, this might be a good opportunity to give it a try.

item.title: Jacquard 03: Setting Up Authentication
item.description: John Anderson (genehack) continous his series explaining how he is building a Catalyst based project. This time he is using CatalystX::SimpleLogin to add authentication to the application. Code, explanations, tests. It's a great series to learn how to build a real application.

item.title: Explaining Why Moose is Awesome – The Direct Way
item.description: John Wang takes his recent experience explaining why he is using Perl and shows what kind of articles he would like to see. In a nutshell, he tries to show 'How Moose makes Perl more Maintainable than Other Languages'.

item.title: The CPAN Book
item.description: A while ago Alberto Simões started a CPAN book. As he is too busy with his regular work now he asked for contributors. If you like the idea and have some time, this can be a great way to contribute to the community.

item.title: FLOSS Weekly: Episode 189 - Perl Critic
item.description: In this weeks episode of the FLOSS Weekly Randal Schwartz and Aaron Newcomb interview Jeffrey Thalhammer, the developer of Perl::Critic. It's an hour long video (though you can also download the audio only) in which you can about history and the future of Perl Critic. You can hear about the problems the developers encountered but maybe most importantly you can get some ideas how to get started with it and how to convince your manager and your co-workers to use it.

item.title: DENOG3 presentation
item.description: Stanislav Sinyagin gave presentations about 3 Perl-based open-source software products for network management and monitoring: Torrus, Gerty and Mooxu.

item.title: Traveling Salesman without Farmer's Daughter
item.description: Dave Jacoby from /var/log/rant describes his alternative to the well known traveling salesman problem and provides code implementing it.

item.title: Presentazion - a DWIM slides HTML/JS software, with PDF export
item.description: Almost every Perl programmer who ever gave a presentation has written a system for creating slides. Some have done it more than once. This time Michele Beltrame (arthas) shares his own version. It looks simple and very nice and he shared the code as well. I think I'll rewrite mine now, based on ideas from his software :)

item.title: Mojolicious hack of the day: WebSockets
item.description: Sebastian Riedel (sri) showing some code how WebSockets can be used in Mojolicious.

item.title: Validation::Class, Mojolicious::Lite and HTML5 Form Field Rendering
item.description: Al Newkirk (awnstudio) created a screencast for Mojolicious.

item.title: CPAN Testers Summary - October 2011 - Some Great Reward
item.description: In his monthly CPAN Testers report Barbie told us about the e-mail reports that are being sent again, about the updated statistics of the system and that finally they might be able to accept donations.

item.title: TDD Best Practices in Perl
item.description: Viacheslav Tykhanovskyi (vti) collected the best practices of TDD (Test Driven Development)

item.title: Testing a simple Perl module
item.description: When starting a new module it is very easy to start writing unit tests from the beginning. In this article you can learn how to use the Perl testing framework in the most simple way. This article marks the renewal of the Test Automation Tips newsletter. If you are interested, please subscribe.

item.title: Linter in Test::WWW::Mechanize
item.description: I was a bit surprised to see Mark Keating (mdk) writing about Perl code and not only about marketing and organizing things but maybe the fresh air in San Francisco had its effects.

item.title: Examining MP3 Tags
item.description: Solomon Foster (colomon) takes the newly release Niecza Perl 6 for a ride to handle his collection of 23,564 MP3 files.

item.title: Public Perl Training classes in Australia
item.description: Damian Conway is going to give 4 public training classes in Melbourne and Brisbane. I guess I don't need to explain why is it great to hear the Perl Best Practices from its author. OTOH I was lucky to see part of the Presentation Aikido at YAPC::EU in Riga. It is great. If you give public talks (e.g. at conferences) it is worth attending.

item.title: Lots of new entries in the Perl Tutorial
item.description: I think I published 5 new entries in the Perl Tutorial I have been writing. They are all more or less equal in importance so instead of pointing out one of them, I am linking to the main page of the whole tutorial.

item.title: Helping people find good Perl tutorials
item.description: In this article I was trying to encourage the Perl community to help the newbies by directing them to the good Perl Tutorials. At the end of the article you can find a link to the new web site of Christian Walde (Mithaldu) catalouging the Perl tutorials.

item.title: Perl Tutorial Hub
item.description: Christian Walde (Mithaldu) started a listing and evaluating all the Perl tutorials on the Internet. It would be of great help if you could also help him.

item.title: London Perl Workshop (LPW2011)
item.description: November 12, 2011, London, UK

item.title: The Perl Oasis
item.description: January 13-15, 2012, Orlando, Florida, USA

item.title: German Perl workshop
item.description: March 5-7, 2012, Erlangen, Germany
